PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
1.  A project preparatory technical assistance (PPTA) is required to prepare the Samarkand 
Solar Power Project, and assist in pre-implementation works.   
 
A.  Justification 
 
2.  The PPTA is necessary on the following grounds:  
 
(i)  The project is the first of its kind in Uzbekistan and in Central Asia, and is 
urgently needed and needs to be prepared in a short period of time.  
(ii)  The government is keen to invest in the project but the executing agency, SJSC 
Uzbekenergo,  has  no  experience  and  no  capacity  in  designing  and  in 
implementing  this  pioneering  large  scale  grid-connected  solar  photovoltaic 
project. A policy and advisory technical assistance (PATA) is conducting onsite 
measurements and safeguards due diligence, and preparing the feasibility study, 
further technical assistance is needed for technical and financial due diligence to 
process a loan for the project, prepare conceptual engineering design and tender 
documents, and to provide assistance to procurement;  
(iii)  There  is  a  need  for  expertise from  international  and  national  consultants  to 
undertake  the  pre-implementation  works,  and  build  the  executing  agency’s 
capacity, considering the project’s demonstration and replication potential.

C.  Cost Estimate and Proposed Financing Arrangement  
 
4.  The PPTA is estimated to cost $750,000 equivalent, the entire amount of which will be 
financed on a grant basis by the Multi-Donor Clean Energy Fund under the Clean Energy 
Financing  Partnership  Facility,  administered  by  ADB.  The  government  will  provide  in-kind 
contribution (office space, furniture, and counterpart staff), the value of which is estimated to 
equal  30%  of  the  TA  cost.  The  detailed  cost  estimate  is  presented  in  Table  A4.2.  The 
government has been informed that the approval of the TA does not commit ADB to finance any 
ensuing project.

D.  Consulting Services 
 
5.  The PPTA will engage (i) a consulting firm using the quality- and cost-based selection 
method (quality: cost weighting of 80:20) biodata technical proposals modality; and (ii) individual 
consultants, following ADB's Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from 
time to time). There are 5 international positions with 19 person-months input, and 4 national 
experts with 24 person-months inputs (See Table A4.3).

6.  The PPTA, among other tasks, needs to adequately address the following aspects 
relating to the ensuing project: (i) detailed loan executing agency capacity assessment (specific 
to grid-connected solar power plants), and suggest remedial action plan to build executing 
agency capacity to minimize procurement and financial management risks; (ii) indicative loan-
related procurement plan with suggested level of priority; and (iii) proposed implementation 
schedule with sequencing of consultant recruitment and procurement bidding and awarding.  
 
7.  The outline terms of reference for the PPTA consultants are in paragraphs 8-10. 
 
8.  The first phase of the PPTA will review the existing feasibility study conducted under the 
ongoing PATA1 including at least a review of the solar resource assessment,  configuration, 
scope, cost estimates, procurement and implementation plans, financial and economic analysis,  
grid impact and synchronization analysis. The PPTA will develop the design criteria, conceptual 
system design, technical specifications and drawings for the power plant and grid connection, 
contract packages, implementation arrangements, and procurement plans. The next phase 
includes preparation of bidding documents for the engineering, procurement, and construction 
turnkey  contract,  and  assistance  to  tendering.  The  consultants  shall  review  the  executing 
agency  financial  management  assessment  (FMA)  and  procurement  capacity  assessment 
conducted under the PPTA for the Takhiatash Power Plant Efficiency Improvement Project.2 
The consultants will also develop and conduct capacity building seminars, workshops, manuals 
including on solar grid integration and O&M to enhance EA capacity. 
 
 
9.  The PPTA consultants shall work closely with the PATA consultants in the review of the 
feasibility study, and coordinate with the Takhiatash PPTA consultants on the update of the 
capacity  assessment  reports.  The  consultants  will  assist  Uzbekenergo  and  other  relevant 
agencies, such as OJSC Teploelectroproyekt (Design Institute), in preparing their feasibility 
study, and assist in pre-implementation works, including but not limited to the following tasks:  
(i)  Review and update existing feasibility study including the scope, solar resource 
assessment,  cost  estimates, financial,  economic,  and  sustainability  analyses, 
grid impact, stability, and synchronization analysis, technical specifications and 
drawings,  procurement  plan,  implementation  plan,  funds  flow,  disbursement 
projections, financial reporting, auditing and disclosure arrangements   
(ii)  Review  the  Project  Administration  Manual  and  prepare  the  loan-related 
procurement  and  implementation  plans;  review  and  update  the  FMA  and 
procurement capacity assessment and prepare a capacity development plan 
(iii)  Develop  the  design  criteria  and  the  conceptual  engineering/system  design 
(propose an optimum system based on the analysis including best configuration)  
(iv)  Assist and provide recommendations to the executing agency in developing their 
feasibility  study  and  basic  engineering  design  including  due  diligence  on 
executing agency-conducted site surveys such as geotechnical, topographic, and 
hydrological studies 
(v)  Develop a capacity development plan and conduct training workshops to provide 
the executing agency and other relevant agencies training and capacity building 
for procurement, new technology management, risk management, operation and 
maintenance of solar power plants and grid integration, including preparation of 
manuals and system design books for executing agency personnel as well as 
operation and maintenance (O&M) manuals.  
(vi)  Prepare technical specifications and drawings of the entire solar power plant 
system, transmission  system,  auxiliary  and  support facilities, foundations/civil 
works

(vii)  Prepare  bidding  documents  and  assist  the  executing  agency  in  tendering 
procedures including  clarification, pre-bidding meeting and issue addendum as 
required 
(viii)  Be  a  member  in  the  procurement  committee  and  prepare  minutes  of  the 
committee meeting; Assist the executing agency in evaluating bids including 
preparing Bid Evaluation Reports (BERs) in accordance with ADB’s Procurement 
Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time).  
(ix)  Provide inputs to relevant sections of ADB’s Report and Recommendation of the 
President (RRP), including all the supporting reports and linked documents. 
(x)  Provide additional services as reasonably requested by the executing agency 
and ADB to process the loan for the project 
 
10.  The PPTA consultants will submit the following reports in both English and Russian:  (i) 
inception  report,  (ii)  2  interim  reports:  1)  updates  on  the  feasibility  study  and  Project 
Administration  Manual  including  a  proposed  implementation  schedule  and  a  capacity 
development plan, and 2) design criteria and conceptual system design, (iii) midterm report 
providing technical drawings and specifications to prepare for the tendering process, (iv) bidding 
documents, (v) bid evaluation reports, and, (vi) final report. At least 3 training and capacity 
building seminars will be conducted in Tashkent and Samarkand, plus one workshop after 
submission of the draft final report. The consultants will also prepare regular monthly reports 
that highlight issues affecting timely completion of the PPTA.  The individual consultants shall 
report to the team leader and prepare sections of reports relevant to their scope and expertise. 
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
11.  SJSC Uzbekenergo will be the executing agency for the PPTA. A Project Management 
Unit will help implement the project and will work closely with the consultants. The EA will 
provide support to the consultants, including (i) arranging meetings with relevant Government 
stakeholders  and  site  visits;  (ii)  providing  access  to  all  relevant  data  and  maps;  and  (iii) 
providing a suitably furnished office (desks, office chairs, book shelves/cabinets adequate to 
accommodate the full complement of international and local consultants) with utilities, national 
and international telephone lines, electricity, air conditioning/heating, and internet connections. 
The consultants will be responsible for personal computers/other facilities for producing reports.  
 
12.  Disbursements  under  the  PPTA  will  follow  the  ADB's  Technical  Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (May 2010, as amended from time to time). The PPTA is expected to 
be implemented over 8 months from May 2013 to January 2014. The proposed TA processing 
and implementation schedule is in Table A4.4.
